And it surprises me greatly that such Gentlemen
who perhaps never learned to paint
know how to write so picturesquely (schilderachtig)
about our clever secrets,
that I think we should content ourselves
with this example of how one can make additions.
left-middleOn the Veil which I have discussed in the chapter on Drawing, on abundant and simple Histories.

63. Further, it is well known that on the World’s stage
There are all kinds of players:
here one sees the King disputing
over Crown and Scepter; elsewhere on stage
young lovers in foolish quarrels;
here Farmers slaughtering Pigs,
there, coarse Peasant Women frolicking and jumping;
over there, Goddesses arrayed in revelry.

64. This I believe, that from the marvelously many colors,
forms and essences, all the gestures
employed in the earthly theater,
of vain pleasures and wretched sorrows,
and from all that is available to the Painter,
so he finds enough material to his advantage
to construct perfect compositions
based on the History he has at hand.

65. Further, one can amplify simple Histories
even more, in various ways.
For example, in choosing to amplify
the simple Sacrifice of Abraham,
one might embellish it with symbolic figures
–that is, Faith, Hope, and Charity–
so that each of these would lend a helping hand
to aid in the Sacrifice.
left-middleHow one may amplify simple Histories even further, be they devotional or otherwise. As an example, the History of the sacrifice of Abraham.

66. Faith might hold Isaac, bound by force,
by the rope; as Abraham stretches out
his hand, Hope offers the knife;
for he hopes to see him again
since God can awaken the dead;
and through Faith he brings him back to that place,
Charity and her children take charge of the fire,
For it burned with fiery coals.

67. A further example here is the annunciation of Zuccaro,
amplified with Angels and Prophets,
and in the Life of Rosso written by Vasari,
we read of a Madonna
with a serpent trampled under her feet,
and also our first Parents sitting in bondage
at the tree of sins, and she withdraws the sin,
represented by an apple, from their mouths.
left-middleExample, the annunciation by Zuccaro, and a Madonna by Rosso, which follows elsewhere in his biography.
